questions.question: 1. What is the primary role of blocking agents in Western blotting?

answers.a: To enhance the binding of primary antibodies
answers.b: To reduce nonspecific binding of antibodies
answers.c: To increase the sensitivity of detection
answers.d: To stabilize the proteins on the membrane

questions.question: 2. In Western blotting, which staining method is commonly used to visualize total protein on the membrane after transfer?
3. What is the main difference between SDS and Native Page?

answers.a: Proteins are denatured for SDS PAGE analysis, but not for NATIVE PAGE
answers.b: Proteins are detected using antibodies for SDS PAGE, an oligomers for NATIVE Page
answers.c: NATIVE PAGE involves stacking gel, while SDS PAGE does not
answers.d: SDS PAGE separates proteins based on size and charge, while NATIVE PAGE separates proteins based only on size

questions.question: 4. What is the primary purpose of Western blotting?

answers.a: To measure the concentration of DNA in a sample
answers.b: To detect specific proteins in a sample
answers.c: To determine the pH level of a solution

questions.question: 5. Which of the following is NOT a step in the Western blotting process?
6. What type of gel is commonly used in Western blotting for protein separation?
7. Which type of gel electrophoresis is typically used to separate proteins by their size in Western blotting?
8. What is the primary function of the stacking gel in SDS-PAGE?

answers.a: To separate proteins based on their size
answers.b: To concentrate and align proteins before they enter the resolving gel
answers.c: To transfer proteins to the membrane

questions.question: 9. What is the typical pH of the stacking gel used in SDS-PAGE?
10. What is the typical pH of the resolving gel in SDS-PAGE?
